Award.AwardTitle: Data Fusion of Heterogeneous Sensor Measurements for Enhanced Structural Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to effectively combine the qualities of different sensor types of a dynamic monitoring network to capitalize on the intrinsic redundancies of the measured data to identify the structural model parameters. Currently there is increasing activity in the area of structural health monitoring using newly emerging, dynamic sensor technologies. There is, however, no clear framework to best combine these heterogeneous measurement quantities for health monitoring purposes. In this project, this dual parameter and state estimation problem with different types of sensor measurements is formulated as a nonlinear estimation problem. In this study, the challenges that will be addressed in dealing with this nonlinear dual state and parameter estimation problem are: 1) the implementation of the approach to large structural problems with many unmeasured states and parameters to be identified and 2) determining the required sensor configurations and resolution to ensure "observability" such that the measured quantities are, indeed, useful and usable for this nonlinear estimation problem. The theoretical developments and the proposed identification approach will be experimentally validated with the laboratory model of a building structure and also with a leveraged data set from a major long-span bridge collected by the principal investigator.

This study is expected to provide a validated approach to maximize the return on the use of the heterogeneous sensor networks and an important practical tool to the structural engineering community for better health monitoring, management and maintenance of critical civil infrastructure system with improved life safety. The PI has an industry/agency outreach plan, and will rapidly introduce the dual state-parameter estimation concepts in a graduate course under development. The project will also provide advanced training to graduate and undergraduate students through their direct involvements in this project.

Institution.Name: Columbia University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK, THE

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The research project introduced techniques to use deformation data (strains, displacements, accelerations or other) from different sensors monitoring a structural system to estimate unmeasured states as well as to identify parameters of an assumed model of the system. This "fusion" of data from different sensors has the advantage of denoising the state estimates as well as enhancing the performance of the parameter and state estimates. In addition to demonstrating this fusion approach using several Bayesian techniques which work in near real-time, the research also addressed the question of what needs to be measured in order to identify parameters of a given model or observe a given unmeasured state. This explored the requirements for nonlinear system observability and identifiability - in effect, answering the question of how to determine whether a sensor configuration (type and location) is sufficient to be able to estimate states or parameters. The data fusion techniques were demonstrated using both simulated mode data sets as well as on experimental data produced by the PI. Toward the end of the research period, research began together with outside collaborators on a closely related problem of jointly estimating the unmeasured input with the unmeasured states in the presence of modeling error. Research results have been submitted for publication review. One other research thread developed during the project which was originally not anticipated. This focused on the specific identification of damping from structures (usually bridges) which are loaded by traffic or other quasi-periodic loading patterns. Several key analysis and potential solution articles have been published. 

Broader Impacts: This work will have an impact in applications of structural health monitoring. The PI has begun to use the techniques in real applications of structural monitoring, and from journal citations it is clear that the ideas have bled out to the applications of other researchers. Through the course of this research several graduate students were trained and they have gone on to academic positions at top universities. The PI together with graduate students who worked on this projected have given many presentations in a variety of conference and seminar settings. The PI has presented this work to practicing structural engineers as part of professional development education programs, and has also presented at two different short course venues targeted at US and international graduate students and resarchers. 


Last Modified: 10/22/2015
Modified by: Andrew W Smyth
